title: clip glass prusa MK2
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - Share Alike

description.text:
I love my prusa mk2 and I wanted to print on glass with it, so I checked out techtiptricks video on youtube about that: https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=VQNCvE2OLhA

The gcode to do this is available on prusamk2.com: http://www.prusamk2.com/printing-on-glass-with-youre-prusa-i3-mk2-ohhh-so-smooth/

Unfortunately all my clips to hold the glass didn't work verry well and were often been pulled away by the extruder, like in techtipricks video. So I created my own clips that can be integrated into the heatbed and don't desturbe the extruder.

Heres the manual how you install them on your prusa mk2 (compare the pictures):

  • unscrew all the 6 screws (2 front, 2 back, 2 middle) that hold the heatbed to the printer
  • put the 4 hex-nut-pieces into the four bottom-clip-parts (FL,FR,BL,BR). Make sure that they are under the bottom-clip-parts!
  • clean the top-clip parts and put some M3x16 screws through them. let them stand out a little bit like shown on the pictures
  • combine all the bottom-clip-parts and the top-clip-parts exept the BL-part by screwing them together. let some space between both parts.
  • put on the clips together with the already entered hex-nut-parts under the hex-nuts of the heatbed. Make sure the hex-nut-parts are NOT on top (compare pictures). the clips are labled: FL (front left), FR (front right), BL (back left), BR (back right).
  • tighten all the screws to the heatbed again. ATTENTION: Make sure the white cable from under the heatbed doesn't get jammed by the BL-clip (should go right around it)!
  • now put the top-clip-part and the BL-clip together with the screws.
  • put the glass on the heatbed and close all clips. Then tighten all screws until the clips hold the glass tight an can be removed easely. Make shure the screws dont poke out from the top-clip parts, especially not on the FL- and the FR-parts! If they poke out to much, they can get in contact with the extruder.

GCODE: This is the gcode I use on my printer for the starting procedure. Make sure you adapt it for yours:

  • G1 Z2.0 : Enter the thickness of your glass in this line of code (in this example 2.0 millimeters)
  • You got 2 minutes to insert the glass (beep after the first minute)

G21 ; set units to millimeters
G90 ; use absolute positioning
M82 ; absolute extrusion mode
M104 S{material_print_temperature} ; set extruder temp
M140 S{material_bed_temperature} ; set bed temp
M190 S{material_bed_temperature} ; wait for bed temp
M109 S{material_print_temperature} ; wait for extruder temp
G92 E0.0 ; reset extruder distance position
G80 ; mesh bed leveling
G1 Y-3.0 F1000.0 ; go outside printing area
G1 F600 Z+30
G4 P30000 ; pause for 1 minute
M300 S1567 P240 ; Play a Beep
M117 One minute remaining ; One minute remaining warning
G4 P30000 ; pause 1 more minute
G1 Z2.0 ; consider glass thickness Measure your glass thickness first
G92 Z0 ; Set absolute positioning for remaining print
G1 X60.0 E9.0 F1000.0 ; intro line
G1 X100.0 E12.5 F1000.0 ; intro line
G92 E0.0 ; reset extruder distance position

Thats it :-) Now you got a mk2 with mounted clips that are not influenced by the extruder and can be removed easely to take out the glass. Have fun! :-)

Printer:

Prusa i3 MK2

Rafts:

No

Supports:

No

Resolution:

0.4 mm

Infill:

30%

description.text:
EDIT: SILENCER PART 1 WAS NOT SCALED PROPERLY! I'VE UPLOADED THE FIX, SO FEEL FREE TO RE-DOWNLOAD

A FULLY CUSTOMIZABLE Assault rifle from Halo 5 Guardians sliced up and ready to print! Every piece is scaled according to the Official Halo Visual Guide, so this is a 100% accurate prop! I've added a build guide that labels the parts and where they go (since there's a lot) and arranged each piece to minimize overhang and use of support material. just download and print!

WARNING: the magazine doesn't fit into the magazine well properly. in the game, the magazine clips through a part of the mesh of the AR model, so when you print this, the hole will only be about half the size you need. My solution would be to glue part 14 to part 15, and part 16 to part 17, then measure how far up it goes, trace the shape, and cut it out of the pieces.

Also, the shape of the longshot scope's rail attachment doesn't match the rails on the AR. either way, i doubt there are many printers that could print a functional rail system that didn't get jammed or broken, so i'd recommend either gluing them on or putting magnets in to change them out.

Want to see more, go visit my Thingiverse page to see my other models!

RECOMMENDED SETTINGS:
Quality: medium to high (depending on your patience)
Support material: minimal
Infill: 5-10% (to save time/filament)

comments.text: How many rolls of filament did you go through to build this?
comments.author: Charles12373

comments.text: Depending on your infill, you will most likely hit 3 rolls.  This is not a cheap build, but pretty amazing.  I would hold off on printing ar_10 until you have made fixes to it as it prints with a gap in the bottom.  Everything else is pretty straight forward.
comments.author: Charles12373

comments.text: Great model, but definitely some funky geometry here and there. AR_10 in particular is highly problematic; I've been able to clean up the other parts with TinkerCAD prior to printing, but AR_10 seems to be FUBAR.
comments.author: Spoon06

comments.text: People seem to have varying degrees of FUBAR depending on their slicers (for some unknown reason). however, i've already made this, and all the funky holes and stuff could be easily patched with spot putty/bondo filler. since my 3D modeling skills are rather lacking, it's what i recommend people do instead of spending hours trying to fix the 3D model itself.
comments.author: Spoon06

comments.text:
gotta ask though, what size are these files made for?
the complete rifle reaches 1 meter long?
or is it scaled to something more human sized?
comments.author: Lunario

comments.text: All my props are scaled according to the Official Halo Visual guide, which gives the dimensions of pretty much every weapon and tool in the Halo universe. however i did go and double check, because it looked off to me. but all the pieces are scaled according to the official guide. a good thing to remember is that everything in halo is bigger than you think, because you spend the whole game as a 7 foot tall spartan! (that's why normal marines look so small and why the guns look so huge when they're holding them) if you want to tweak the scale for a kid's costume or just to have it be a bit more comfortable, you can scale the full prop model (included in the download) to your desired size, then take the adjusted scale ratio and copy/paste it for all the different pieces.
comments.author: Lunario

comments.text: thats awsome, because i printed a ma37 and i had to scale it 20%down to make it 800 cms long. probably gonna have to do the same for this one. will have to see as i print one or 2 pieces so i can make it easier. love the model :) doing some repairs on it to prevent bugs on the printing or the printer will print it to weak as some walls are missing
comments.author: misterchiefcostuming

comments.text: Did you managed to get the walls patched up? Are you using Netfab for that or something else? I've got walls missing on a few models as well so wasnt sure if it was just me or not.
comments.author: Lunario

comments.text: Its not just you, there is some gnarly geometry. however, i'm about 80% finished printing it, and the missing walls are VERY small and can easily be patched up with bondo or whatever filler you prefer.

Last year my cousin hand-built a timber frame cabin in the woods of Northern Minnesota. This one-room building has no water or electricity, just a wood burning stove and a sleeping loft with lots of blankets.
This model is made from a CAD model he constructed before starting the real thing. I printed it as a single piece, though it requires a lot of support--it should probably be printed in several pieces and glued together.
He now has this cabin as constructed using both primitive hand tools and the latest in modern 3D printing technology. Only one version is big enough to sleep in, however.

description.text:
A E3D hotend mount. Suited for the Ultimaker original and maybe the Ultimaker 2 (not tested). Its designed for optimal space and isn't taking more space than te bearings are long, so maximum travel guaranteed.

It works on 3 30mm fans and comes together with all metric m3 screws for the fans. The hotend clamp uses 2 m3 screws and 2 m3 hex nuts in the bearing space so it really can be tightened (make sure you put the nuts in first). For holding the bearing i used 4 m3 setscrews to be sure no play starts there. Besides that it uses 4 zip ties for the cables.

Good luck printing and don't forget to post your make.

description.text:
Being that the Monoprice Mini Select/Malyan M200 is so small, it's easy to move around and bring back and forth to the shop. Carrying it was awkward, bed sliding everywhere. So I found a handle on here and remixed it so it fits 2 of the M3 screws on the top of the tower.

I bought a package of M3x22mm socket head screws from Home Depot and they worked perfect. I saved the washer from the 2 screws removed from the tower and used them on the new screws.

Print in 100% infill

This is remixed from this design: http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:12695

UPDATE
I made a slight modification to the height of the legs, I was hitting my knuckles sometimes on the filament feeder. I added 4mm to the height which should add a little bit of clearance.

UPDATE
The new height is perfect, no more knuckle hitting. Recommend a small dab of removable loctite on the screws.

I've uploaded v2.1 which also has a notch cut out for clearance.

UPDATE

Took out the ribs. I hated them. So did other people. Nice and round now.

title: Basic Adafruit PiTFT - 2.8" Resistive Touchscreen Display

description.text:
Model of the: Adafruit PiTFT - 2.8" Resistive Touchscreen Display

Made this as I needed to put the real thing inside a vacuum former, screens and vacuum formers don't usually mix well...

Would say this is pretty accurate, made using the resources on the adafruit site and measuring my own with callipers. Plan to update with a more detailed version in the future, i.e add an underside etc but for my plans this was unneeded as the plastic only impacts the top of the display.

Hopefully this could be useful for people planning builds or for similar uses to me, i've included the sketchup file for people if they want to adjust/check accuracy for their own projects.

Will upload an image of the print when I get it back from the workshop.

Resources:

Diagram - https://learn.adafruit.com/adafruit-pitft-28-inch-resistive-touchscreen-display-raspberry-pi/downloads

Display - https://www.adafruit.com/products/2298

comments.text: Excellent design. I thank SPACETOOH.  I used it to create a case for an internet radio I built out of a Raspberry Pi Zero, this PiTFT, and a pHAT DAC (from Pimoroni).  It worked.  One comment.  The corners on this shape are rounded with a radius that is too long.  The corners on the actual board (at least mine) are much tighter than that.  Where this becomes an issue is if you were to make the above a void and sink it into a surface slightly.  The board won't press in because the corners will snag, if that makes sense.  So ... if you plan to use this as a void and sink it into a surface, it's not hard to square the corners.
comments.author: lonchdomas

title: DiscoEasy 200 Tendeur de courroie Y intégrée support plateau
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - Share Alike

description.text:
Le principe de tension de courroie Y sous le plateau de la DiscoEasy 200 est vraiment pas pratique (retourner toute la machine pour y avoir acces ou alors démonter le plateau...pas pratique avec un buildtak) et ne semble pas garder la tension de la courroie très longtemps.
Je suis donc parti du Step fourni par Dagoma pour y incorporer l'attache des 2 bouts de courroies et permettre un resserage facilité.
Pour y avoir accès, simplement mettre le plateau à fond vers l'arriere de la machine et un tournevis passe entre la facade avant et le support du plateau : plus besoin de démonter ni de retourner la machine.

Nécessite :

  • 2 vis M3-40 CHC
  • 4 vis M3-6 FHC
  • 2 écrous M3 nylstop de préférence

En WORK IN PROGRESS car pas encore imprimer/tester/éprouver.

Pour la compréhension du montage de la courroie, j'ai ajouté des images. En bleu ciel, la face de la courroie comportant les crans. Donc pas de probleme de sens des stries sur les pièces du tendeur. :-)

comments.text: Bonjour. Il est fonctionnel ou pas tel qu'il est sur le site ?
comments.author: agglax

comments.text: Bonjour, en théorie oui. Par contre, du fait des tolérances d'impression, propre à chaque machine, il n'est pas impossible qu'il faille faire quelque modif. Ne l'ayant pas encore mis en oeuvre (en vrai), faute de temps pour le moment, je laisse le statut WIP.
comments.author: agglax

comments.text: Bonsoir, d'un coté, la courroie est prise en sandwich dans la partie qui sera fixé sous le plateau. L'autre extrémité de la courroie sera prise en sandwish dans la partie mobile. Ce sont les longues vis qui permettent de faire coulisser la partie mobile sur la partie fixe et permet justement de tendre la courroie. Dès que je peux, j'essaye de modéliser ce que cela donne et surtout dès que j'aurai trouvé les bons parametres d'un sliceur (probleme d'impression pour tenir des cotes internes exactes), je mettrais en application :)

title: MIGBOT Z - Endstop limit adjustment
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - Share Alike

description.text: Can easily micro-adjust the height of the nozzle off the bed by turning the adjustment knob 1/8 to 1/4 of a turn. Is great when changing filaments and having to reset the Z offset. After you have used it a while you will get a feeling for just how far to turn the adjustment. Move it slightly, hit "Z Home" and see the results.

Printer:

Migbot i3

Rafts:

No

Supports:

No

Resolution:

.2

Infill:

30

Notes:

Lay the "Z - Limit switch adjust adjustment holder" on the back with the nut slots and the mounting screw indents up.

Reasoning behind build:

I always had difficulty adjusting the Z-end stop limit switch. It was hard to get it positioned perfectly, then try and hold it in place while tighten up the mounting clamp. The switch moved to easily up and down and all around the 8 mm polished rod. It was to easily bumped out of position. Wanted something that I could easily mirco-adjust, and was repeatable.

Parts:

(1) 4 inch 6-32 machine screw (mine actually came off an old toogle bolt)
(4) 6-32 nuts
(2) small washers
(1) small 3/4 long spring

Notes:

The first one I made was for a Migbot i3 (manufactured by Electron). I made another later for a HIC - Mendel i3. The HIC -Mendel version needed a slightly different "Spacer Block". The spacer block is necessary to keep the limit switch mounting bracket from spinning around on the 8 mm polished rod.

Since it uses the stepper motor mount bolts to hold it in place, you may have to use slightly longer metric bolts there.

title: OpenForge 2.0 Spiral Stair Down (ORIG) OpenLock Base

description.text:
OpenForge 2.0 and OpenLock
A roleplaying terrain feature/accessory to depict a spiral staircase going down. The first step is a trip hazard, as OpenForge has thicker floors, the first tread is a little high, but serves to provide that roleplaying feel for a set of stairs going down (grinds against the OCD mind). Was asked to do this, so I scrunched the brain to try to get a close proximity to a roleplaying accessory. Not a high wall, but could be in the middle of the floor, so a good option.

Modified xloud's spiral staircase (down) for OpenForge to the OpenForge 2.0/OpenLock 4.0 standards. Resized to 25.4x50.8. Includes both 1" thick base wall A and B to link the standard E or EA tiles...well to a degree. The DOWN aspect prevents a true A and B attachment from the front, but is true on the backside of the tile. Will need an EA tile to attach the front for both tile types.

Note! have not printed to verify compatibility as of 02/16/17.

title: Outrageously Overengineered Filament Stand for ANY Size Reel

description.text:
I recently bought a 30-lb reel of filament from Protoparadigm. This is much cheaper than buying the stuff a kilogram at a time, but there is no practical way to hang that size reel off the side of my printer.
Thus was born the Outrageously Overengineered Filament Stand. It consists of two towers, each topped with a ball bearing and a socket for an axle. An axle goes between the towers, and a pair of centering rings keep the reel centered on the axle.
The whole thing is 100% 3D printed with no connectors, screws, or other components. Some ABS glue may be useful but isn't necessary.
The height of the towers, length of the axle, and diameter of the centering rings can vary to accommodate different size reels. I have used this with five different size reels.

Print two of the Top and the Base, and 2-4 pairs of Tower Segments. Assemble these to make your towers. Additional Tower Segments can be used to make taller towers for larger diameter reels, but I've found that four segments in each tower is enough for the largest reels I've come across. You may want to glue the tower together for easier handling.
I've provided Axles and Centering Rings for a variety of reel sizes. Print an axle with length close to the height (thickness) of your reel, and two centering rings with diameter close to the diameter of the center hole of your reel.
Put the axle and centering rings through your reel, then put each end of the axle on an assembled tower. If assembled properly, it takes very little force to turn even a large reel of plastic.

title: Monoprice maker select plus washers for bed adjustment

description.text:
I am on my third Monoprice Maker Select and the bed leveling is difficult. The z stop is always cocked and you have to back off the screws so far they almost fall off. So, I used the insulated washer and added the 0.1 washer to the base and after leveling the x axis with 2 CD cases, I leveled the bed in 2 minutes and was printing in 10. This was the fastest setup I have ever done.

NOTE: YOU NEED TO ALSO PRINT THE HEAT BED SPRING WASHER. PLACE EITHER 0.05 or 0.1 (I USED O.1) UNDER SPRING WASHER. Do two at a time, you dont have to do 4 at once.

IT WAS RIDICULOUS HOW QUICK IT WAS TO LEVEL AFTER DAYS OF STRUGGLING WITH COUNTER SCREWS ETC.

EDIT : - Created my own cupped washer in MP washer file

comments.text: I am having the exact same issue, can you show a completed picture so I can understand how this moves the plate up?
comments.author: hevnsnt

comments.text: Think tension. When you add a spacer(s) between the plate and bed, the spring is compressed more than it would be. This in turn puts greater force down toward the screw, and thus you can raise the bed further as there is more force/ compression. You also need to adjust your X z endstop. The limit switch/ end stop is attached to the vertical frame by two small allen screws. Loosen them and push the endstop/screws down. This will also lower you Z height. This also means you will have to bring the height of the bed down further which increases the compression on the springs. If that makes no sense, dont worry, just try it, it will work.
comments.author: hevnsnt

Those parts will reduce flex of A2 Z-axis and therefore reduce Z sagging, which causes first layers to be crushed on top of each other, a lot of extruder clicking, elephant foot and prints being several tenths of mm lower than they should be. In standard form my A2 produced prints that were 0.6-0.7mm lower than designed, all due to Z sag and flex. Those parts eliminate most of it, my prints are now less than 0.1 off. The stabilizer actually contributes more, so if you want to have a quick win, just use the stabilizer.
Picture shows older version of the motor mount which, as I later discovered, limits Z travel ~12mm, so the STL has a cutout in the bottom part for the wheel (black marker on the photos).

UPDATE: I have now switched to inverted Z http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:2199187, and like it even more than this thing. Even though it's created for dual lead screws, I'm currently using it with single stock one, waiting for my parts to arrive. 100% Z sag eliminated. It is a bit more difficult to align due to short distance between motor and Z nut at Z=0 height, but once it's sorted, it's excellent.
If you are a fresh A2 owner just starting up, I suggest just printing the small stabilizer part from this thing here and using it to print the inverted Z parts.

Notes:

I printed mine in PLA with 100% infill. Motor mount should be printed upside down, no need for supports. the stabilizer can be printed laying down (no need for supports), or like I did, standing up, in which case it obviously needs internal supports.
The motor mount is intentionally designed with zero tolerance, the width of the frame slot is exactly 20mm, so make sure your printer is producing OK measurements in XY dimension. Else you could probably scale it 101% in slicer to give you some slack.

comments.author: igal

comments.text: I believe I already wrote in the description that majority of the benefits actually come from the stabilizer around the flex coupler. The stock coupler flexes too much when it goes from downward movement (during print start) to upward movement (moving to next layer), causing first layers to be crushed to each other. This stabilizer slightly compresses the coupler when installed, so that the coupler will not shorten as much when going down, and it doesn't allow the coupler to expand when going up, reducing the sag (or backlash) significantly. In addition to solving the initial layer issues, it also makes height of all layers more stable, as the coupler does not "randomize" as much.

description.text: A pentagonal succulent planter for Mother's Day 2017. It is about 7"x7"x4". Pretty small, but looks nice. Great last minute gift for the procrastinator in all of us. Says, "Mother's Day 2017." It also contains five holes, one in each corner, for draining the water from the pot, to prevent drowning of the plants. Simple little pot for you simple little plants. Enjoy!

Rafts:

Inspiration

It was actually a school assignment sooo...

History

In botany, succulent plants, also known as succulents or sometimes water storage plants, are plants that have some parts that are more than normally thickened and fleshy, usually to retain water in arid climates or soil conditions. The word "succulent" comes from the Latin word sucus, meaning juice, or sap. Succulent plants may store water in various structures, such as leaves and stems. Some definitions also include roots, so that geophytes that survive unfavorable periods by dying back to underground storage organs may be regarded as succulents. In horticultural use, the term "succulent" is often used in a way which excludes plants that botanists would regard as succulents, such as cacti. Succulents are often grown as ornamental plants because of their striking and unusual appearance.
https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Succulent_plant

Design Process

Super easy to make. I made a pentagon and extruded it, then made a smaller pentagon inside of it and extruded that too. Then I used the BooleanDifference function to cut the middle out. Then added text. Like I said, easy. But not as easy as it is to download it and print it off.

title: Printrbot Play Spool Holder For Spools of More Sizes

description.text:
So I recently purchased a large 5 pound roll of MatterHackers Pro PLA in Silver, and well, it was as big as my printer so a new solution was needed.

Just like the stock spool holder, no extra or longer screws are needed, just remove and re-install the stock ones with the new brackets in between.

For this solution you're going to need:
A Printrbot Play to mount it to (kind of meant to mount to it afterall)
Four 608 Bearings (skateboard / rollerblade bearings)
Two 8mm Smoothrods, or M8 bolts, or something cylindrical that fits in the inner opening of the 608 bearings (at least 130mm-ish long)

My Printrbot Play has the Heated Bed, Extended Y-Axis Mod so I had extra smooth rods from the upgrade

If you don't have the extended y-axis, and can't get a friend to print this for you, I'll be working on a Smaller or Multi-Part Variation if wanted. Leave comments if you'd like/need that before it's added here.

description.text: Since upgrading my MakerSelect to the MK2 extruder, I wanted a better way of leveling the bed with my dial gauge. There are a few mounts here on thingiverse but they didn't give me the results I'm looking for. So I designed this one. I've based my design off of this. I started playing around with plotting and I figured I could recreate the design to mount a dial gauge. I did't use any of his files for this thing but I used the idea of mounting it to the stepper.

Printer:

Monoprice Maker Select/Wanhao Duplicator i3

Rafts:

No

Supports:

No

Resolution:

0.2mm

Infill:

30%

Notes:

I printed this with 2 shells which should be sufficient.

Screws

I used the existing screws from the dial gauge to mount the backplate to it.

The screws you will need to mount the printed backplate to the mount are:
2 x M3-5 screws

For the clamp on the top you will need atleast a
1 x M3-10 or longer.

I've also added an indentation for a M3 locknut if you have any laying around. The M3-10 screw I'm using actually threads into the plastic for right now but, I know that will wear out eventually.

description.text:
This is a CoreXY style printer with in the making.

Made with 20x20mm extrusions, Ramps 1.4, 10mm Igus bushing for the Z-axis, THK linear rails for X and Y, TMC2130 drivers for sensorless homing on X and Y and 100mm carbon tubes for the Z-axis and bed assembly.

Not the most reproducible printer due to the use of specific THK linear rails I have left over. But my reason for uploading here is to share and release my FreeCAD files [later changed to Autodesk Fusion] with others.

Updates and documentation will be added depending on my availability. But will use this as a log, and will add to it as often as possible.

Printer:

Prusa I3 clone

Rafts:

Doesn't Matter

Supports:

Yes

Resolution:

0.35

Infill:

50%

Notes:

Printed with E3D Volcano, 0.6mm nozzle using PETG.

Support needed on following parts (only latest revisions)

  • carriage top and bottom

comments.text: Hi sorry for the late reply. I've been away for a while...
comments.author: Piscanc

comments.text: I have to ask, given the frame design you chose I wonder why you didnt go with an H bot instead of the corexy?
comments.author: warham

comments.text:
That's a good question.
Upon reviewing the principles about H-bot vs CoreXY, I came to the conclusion that CoreXY would most likely be a more stabil setup due to the belts relieving stress on both sides of the gantry. Or in other words; on H-bot the A and B belts only pulls on their respective sides. My worry about this is if one side has more slack than the other, a misalignment might occur.
On the CoreXY both belts pulls on each side of the gantry, and this could help out by cancelling misalignment issues.

An interpretation of the printrbot logo from printrbot.com.

This version prints as four separate pieces.  You may want to tweak the sketchup file if you want them to be connected.  The relative widths of the border pieces are slightly off, maybe someone can help me fix that.

By default this prints out about 70mm tall.  You may want to scale it to your desired size. A 40mm tall version will fit nicely on the front of a printrbot+.

title: Automotive Differential with Hypoid Gearing, Motorized Model

description.text:
https://youtu.be/xs2SApdWo20

The automotive differential is something every automobile has: this ingenious mechanism transmits power from the drive shaft at 90° to the driving wheels, while allowing them to rotate at different speeds when the driving conditions call for it, such as during a turn.

This is a motorized model of the most basic kind of automotive differentials, known as the open differential. Unlike most 3D-printable differential models out there, this one is equipped with a hypoid, not bevel, pinion/ring gear pair.

The model is powered by a 6V electric motor equipped with a speed reducer. It requires an external power source, such as four AA batteries in a holder, or an old 6V phone charger with stripped wires.

Please visit http://www.otvinta.com/download09.html for detailed and illustrated assembly instructions.

Printer Brand:

MakerGear

Printer:

MakerGear M2

Rafts:

No

Supports:

Yes

Notes:

The pinion needs ample support to ensure smooth meshing with the ring gear. We use Simplify3D and had to add support manually to cover all teeth, No other part needs support beyond the default amount.

You need to print 2 wheels, 2 side gears, 2 spider gears, and 1 of all other parts.

Tutorial: How to Model and Test the Automotive Differential in Blender

We have created a tutorial on how to design the automotive differential in Blender 3D.

Tutorial: How to Model a Hypoid Gear Drive in Blender

We have also created a tutorial on how to design hypoid gears. The Hypoid drive is similar to the bevel drive but the axes of the pinion and gear do not intersect.

title: Linear Bearing Housing - 16mm OD / 8 mm shaft
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - Share Alike

description.text:
First model, so go easy on me. I have not printed this yet but plan to soon, as my printer was shipped to me missing these pieces, so I have to find someone else to print them for me.

I pretty much created this from scratch using the basic shape as a lot of other linear bearing housings in the LM8UU style for 8 mm rod, but this is sized for the bearing with an outer diameter of 16 mm such as the Igus RJZM-01-08 DryLin R Straight Linear Bearing, 8 mm ID: http://a.co/j5OuSFU

I thought the tear-drop shape for the bolt holes was a really good idea for ease of printing without support.

Drawn using CATIA

This is a DB9-DB9 Connector Converter case.
In order to build your connector converter you also need the following parts:

  • two DB9 simple connectors (as in the photos); Depending on what kind of converter you need, you can use male-male, female-female or male-female DB9 connectors.
  • internal connection wires;
    I myself soldered two rows of 2.5 dupont pins on one connector, and on the other connector I soldered connection wires having female dupont headers on one end. In this way you can build a DB9 converter with fully customizable pinout (you can easily switch between crossover or straight-through connections, for instance)

The converter case has 3 parts that need to be printed:

  • the converter case
  • the case lid
  • a small fastening clamp - to keep the lid and the case together

DIY Fix | Mackey's 3D Printer Modify 3

Description:
Designed to be printed at 0.2mm layer height.

Z Axis Frame Assembly has to be changed from 165mm to 155mm.

Highly recommend ABS for printer parts.
How to print ABS:

  1. You have to make a box for the printer, and inside the box should be about 60C.
  2. Prepare the bed. Mix 100g of acetone with 1m of 1.75mm ABS filament to make ABS juice.
  3. Use Foam Poly Brush to apply a thin film of ABS juice to the bed.
  4. You are ready to print ABS.
  5. Avoid ABS shrinkage. After the print is done, don't open your printer's box yet, leave the print to cool down inside until the bed is at about 50C or less. After the bed is at 50C or less, remove the print, and there you have it!

More Photos

Other info:

LCD

  • Problem: If your HICTOP printer is making random weird moves and shutting down when using SD card, it means that part of the LCD screen is touching the metal piece that is touching the Y step motor. If you have the old LCD screen that is all metal, you will have this problem. For your information, HICTOP now provides the metal cover that comes with plastic nuts to separate the LCD screen and the metal cover to fix this problem.
  • Solution: Remove the LCD screen from the printer frame and put it aside. Avoid the LCD ribbon wires touching the step motor wires.

Main Board

  • Problem: From April 2017, HICTOP now has a built-in SD card reader on the main board. Thus, the SD card reader on the LCD is no longer usable.
  • Solution: Buy eBay Amazon MKS Base V1.5 3D Printer Controller Board to replace it.

Loud Converter

  • If your converter's fan is making a loud noise, simply replace the fan with a new one here eBay Amazon 24V 60x60x15mm Fan.

Uneven Bed ABS

  • Problem: If you experience uneven bed when printing ABS out of nowhere, in this case the proximity sensor's temperature matters. If the sensor is cool during the preheat, given that the X carriage is 100mm or more above the bed, when the sensor is doing G29 or probing the bed, the cool sensor will get warmer and warmer throughout the bed and the sensor will give out inaccurate numbers as its temperature changes.
  • Solution: Do Auto Home, and then preheat ABS. In this case the sensor should be about 15mm above the bed and getting warmed up by the bed's temperature. Once the sensor starts to prob the bed, its temperature shouldn't change wildly and it should give out accurate numbers.

PLA Clogging Nozzle, Heat Creep

  • Problem: PLA keeps clogging at the throat even with new nozzle and new throat.
  • Solution 1: Don't use these fan ducts, only use them when printing ABS:
    DKDGWi_3DPDK_X_Carriage_Heat_Sink_Exhaust.stl
    DKDGWi_3DPDK_X_Carriage_Heat_Sink_Intake.stl
  • Solution 2: If it's still clogging, check the heat sink cooling fan, you may need to replace it.
  • Solution 3: If it's still clogging, try blowing cool air through the printer.
  • Solution 4: If it's still clogging, try printing at lower temperature like 200C or 190C.
  • Solution 5: If it's still clogging, throw away your filament, and buy a better quality filament.

Proximity sensor

  • Problem: Proximity sensor wire(s) get broken inside. After a while these wires do get broken especially around the extruder flexing (the first curve).
  • Problem: It might even be serious like it would actually blow up your main board.
  • Solution: Buy new proximity sensor.

Heat drops randomly

  • Problem: Heat drops and the printer stops.
  • Solution: Check the heat sensor wires, they might be broken inside somewhere.

title: Raise3D N2/N2+ Front Mounted Blower Fan for Left Extruder

description.text:
Made some changes to Firesped's bracket to suit my needs. Uploading in case others have similar wants.

Modifications from https://www.thingiverse.com/thing:2089681:

-Moved the duct and shortened it to aim more at the left nozzle instead of being between them (I rarely use right nozzle).
-Used Toby's duct (http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:1355622, I liked its airflow and taller socket for the fan) and repaired the gap in the model.
-Slightly reduced the size of the fan socket for easier fit
-Moved mount screw holes so the duct is 1mm closer to the heater block to increase tolerance for clearing the model.
-Removed the round cutouts that surround the throat tube set screws to make it compatible with later extruder head revisions.

Will probably require a high temp material or an insulated hotend to prevent melting of the duct. Made mine with PLA and it doesn't melt while printing PLA with a lightly insulated hotend (silicone/fiberglass cable sheathing).

Uses the same hardware as Firesped's bracket. Here's what I used:

12V 50x15mm blower fan (https://www.amazon.com/Connector-Cooling-Blower-50mmx15mm-uxcell/dp/B00MJU6JR2).

2x 16mm and 2x 20mm M3 socket cap screws https://www.amazon.com/Hilitchi-210pcs-Stainless-Socket-Assortment/dp/B014ONCP88

2x uxcell M3 3x4x4.3mm thread inserts https://www.amazon.com/uxcell-Female-Knurled-Threaded-Embedded/dp/B01IYWUZ46

I designed this focus ring that you can super glue to your raspberry pi camera. It allows you to easily focus the manual focus lens. IMPORTANT:

author: colinhaynes

description.text:
I needed a way to align my openbeam rail to an existing device built using threaded rod - not a solid attachment, just a relative positioning aid (because both parts need to be worked on independently). So I made this simple clip to do that. Hopefully someone else will also find it useful.

This is part of a system of designs that turns an Open Beam into an optical rail. An optical rail is a long, straight, sturdy rail onto which optical components such as light sources and lenses can be bolted down and easily shifted along the length of the rail.

Commercial optical rail sells for $250+/m. Open beam only costs $12/m for the fancy black anodized stuff. You get the idea.

This component is inspired by the Open-source optics project, whose goal is to radically reduce the cost of scientific optical hardware, by the Michigan Tech's Open Sustainability Technology Research Group.

OpenSCAD code included for modifications. Just print on your favorite 3D printer and clean up.

The fits onto the end of the OpenBeam as seen in the pictures. The provided STL should provide a tight fit for 15mm OpenBeam.

You can get OpenBeam at http://www.openbeamusa.com/

A customisable pot and saucer.

description.text:
I work in Philadelphia, PA (USA) where parking meters have been replaced by kiosks that take your money and generate receipts which must be displayed on the vehicle dashboard. Where I park it's really windy and the receipts often get blown off the dash before I can close the car door. Reminds me of trying to get out of the house without letting the cat escape. This Thing was created to hold the receipt in place so it doesn't get blown away, resulting in a $37 USD parking ticket.

I updated the design slightly so the parking stub lays flat and makes it easier to insert the stub with only one hand. It should be printed with the flat end on the bed (standing up); this gives a smoother finish.

The holder is attached to the dashboard using double-sided tape, which I got at my local Staples. The picture shows the stuff, and it is advertised as being removable and reusable. It could also be affixed to the windshield, I suppose. I hope you find it useful!

LQ-LC01A2 (new version)

This is an updated, and newly created, version of the original LQ-LC01A1 lens cap for the Leica Q Typ 116. The main advantage over the standard lens cap is the lanyard attachment point.

The lens cap now has full compatibility with the Ever Ready Case (19502), and the Day Bag (19504), and is designed to be used as is, without any protective tape around the cap edges. I would however suggest black tape or adhesive felt on the inside of the lenscap, as illustrated - especially if you're printing at 0.2mm, as the cap won't be light-tight.

The cap can be printed without supports given a properly functioning printer - print it upside down, with the Leica logo facing down.

You can use anything for a lanyard, but I'd suggest what I did - which is to buy the really cheap, small nylon wrist lanyards from eBay, cut off the plastic bit, thread the lanyard through the body and the cap, then just slightly melt the ends (& squish it down at the cap with a flat thing while it's cooling) after tying them off.

print_settings.Notes:: I used 4 shells for strength, 30% honeycomb infill. The handle needs supports for the captive nut fittings.

description.text:
Tube rings to mount two telescopes with a 90mm outer tube diameter side-by-side. This works for some ED80/ST80 imaging scope/guide scope combinations, but some ED80s have a 100mm tube diameter.

You need a fairly large print bed for this!

Print 2x top and 2x bottom pieces - the handle is optional but it's convenient and might add some additional stiffness.

It all fits together with M6 bolts, the handle has recesses for 2 captive hex nuts.

I've uploaded the Sketchup files along with the STLs.

  • PLA is probably a bad idea if you're going to keep this in an observatory/shed that gets hot
  • ABS is probably best, but due to the size it's hard to prevent it warping when printing.
  • PETG should work, but it's more flexible than ABS/PLA and you don't want flexure between the imaging scope and guide scope - I haven't tested it.
  • Carbon fibre filaments might be ideal - stiff is good.

Printer:

Hictop Prusa i3 (3DP-17)

Resolution:

0.2

Infill:

30%

Notes:

I used 4 shells for strength, 30% honeycomb infill. The handle needs supports for the captive nut fittings.

title: Toradex Viola + Ipê Stackable Stand / Support

description.text:
This is a stand for the Toradex Viola Plus embedded development board with the add-on board Ipê. It has the following features:

  • It's stackable, which means that if you put one over the other (with the boards), they will perfectly fit and snap;
  • It's discreet, meaning no extra edges getting in the way;
  • It spends a small amount of filament, so it's economic;
  • It has exact fittings for nuts (M3) and screws (M3x8)
  • It's robust, it was even submitted to finite element analysis to solve reinforcement points and a real-life breakage test.

description.text: I wanted a single piece mount that also cooled the hot end and the printed part with a single 40mm fan. I could not find one I was happy with, so I just designed my own. This uses a 40mm fan to cool both the E3D heat break and provides a duct to blow on the part being printed to help cool it. about 70% of the fan is used for the heat break and about 30% for the part. It is designed to mount directly to the Lawsy MK4 extruder (http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:47561) using the 2 mounting holes on the extruder. It also holds the hot end in the extruder mount to keep it more stable. I had a problem with it rocking slightly without a clamp. Please excuse the dirty heat block in the pictures. I really should clean it up, but my printer tends to see a lot of action! :)

I printed mine with 0.3mm layers and 20% infill and supports using T-Glase (PET).   
Now that I look at it again, I really should build some support structure into the bottom part of the part. Cleaning up all the supports was a real pain and it left a lot of scars on what should be a good looking piece.   
After designing the part, I noticed that the bottom was not quite flat, so I just sliced it flat in netfabb. I recommend printing the flat bottom file on a typical FDM machine, but the original is provided just in case.

comments.text: Does the E3D require constant airflow for cooling? I would think you don't want air blowing on the print at all times for ABS or PLA.
comments.author: etreehi

comments.text: the hot end does require airflow to maintain a small thermal barrier. Without the airflow, the heat would creep up into the feed tube and you would get jamming.

author: lazyviking

description.text: Opened in SolidWorks, saved back as STL. Fixed the lettering.

I purchased a garage door insulator kit this winter. Over time the lousy double sided tape included gave way on the bases of many of the holders that keep the insulation in place. In the process of trying to figure out what to do I broke a number of the bases (the top connector where the cover goes would snap a latching piece off). So rather than chuck it all I designed a new set and will be replacing the old double sided tape with industrial variety or construction adhesive.
I thought someone else might find a use for these. I have included the SCAD file for anyone that wants to play around with it a bit. It took 4 attempts to get one that works with my remaining original covers but earlier varieties worked fine, with their own covers.
There is nothing special about the insulation used so there is no reason someone could not use this with just regular insulation or even foam board insulation. In addition it could be used on areas other than garage doors which have fairly smooth surfaces that need to be adhered to.

1) Print out as many sets of bases and covers (1 each per set) as you need for the insulation piece you are installing.
2) Put adhesive (double sided tape but strong varieties since it will hang upside down with a decent amount of weight OR construction adhesive which is less removable) on the bottom of the base and stick in place.
3) Punch a hole through the insulation to be mounted where the base is then put the insulation on the base.
4) Snap a cover into place on top of the base to hold the insulation in place.

title: Kamen Rider Kuuga/クウガ Ultimate Form Helmet

description.text:
A helmet to print for your cosplay...or to gift to your life's greatest blunder, if you've got one ;)

This helmet is intended for cosplay, and is scaled to be wearable for somebody about 5 feet 6 inches (~168 cm) tall. You're likely going to need to scale it up if you're bigger than that (the mask will be tightest from the tip of your nose to the back of your head, so scale based on that measurement). If you just want a miniature version of the helmet, there's official merch line called Mask Collection (マスコレ) that I'd suggest checking out instead of printing this (they've released a new Kuuga Ultimate for it as of September 2017).

Feel free to print via 3dhubs/university printing services/etc. Print mass should be around 200 grams.

Notes:

Sorry for the weird filenames. Here's what they all mean:

40cm is the entire helmet, not sliced into parts or anything. Everything other than the eyes (eyeskuuga) is pieces of the helmet.
26resclaback is the back half of the helmet.
26rescaledtop is the top half of the front half of the helmet. Depending on your printer settings, either print 26rescaledbottom OR 30bottomteeth and 30verybottom.

Print, filler agent (I like to use Bondo on the outside and fiberglass on the inside, but use proper respiratory protection), filler primer, paint.

For the eyes, I printed them out and used them as bucks for vacuum forming some cheap 5x5 inch sheets of PETG I got off ebay. Dyed with idye poly.

Modeled in Blender.

Used a UV sphere, scaled it in the x/y/z directions, and added a subdivision surface modifier to get the base shape. The mouth area and 'ears' were meshes separate from the base UV sphere with a subdivision surface modifier added. The horns used curves that got converted into mesh later. I used a curve to knife project into the base for the basic eye shape in order to make the eyes recessed into the helmet's side a little, then made a separate mesh for the eyes.
Used the bmesh boolean tool to clean it all up, then added a solidify modifier.

title: Dry Erase Marker Tiered Stand for a Desktop/Table

description.text:
While homeschooling, I pulled a sharpie out of the same cup where we were storing the small dry erase markers. Thankfully I realized my mistake in time, but I decided that we needed another location to store our dry erase markers. I couldn't find a design that could organize both large and small Expo dry erase markers. Thus, I decided to design one. We happen to have four large, 6 small, and an eraser, so that's what it holds.

The original design was intended to hold the markers pointed up as in the pictures. I've added a second design which has larger wells for the small markers. Both marker sizes now fit tip-down to keep the ink where it is needed. It is harder to pick the color you want, but hopefully increases their life.

title: Bust of Harriet Tubman
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - Share Alike

description.text:
I've created this model of Harriet Tubman to celebrate Black History Month and Women's History Month.

Harriet Tubman was an American abolitionist, humanitarian, and an armed scout and spy for the United States Army during the American Civil War. Born into slavery, Tubman escaped and subsequently made some thirteen missions to rescue approximately seventy enslaved families and friends, using the network of antislavery activists and safe houses known as the Underground Railroad. She later helped abolitionist John Brown recruit men for his raid on Harpers Ferry, and in the post-war era was an active participant in the struggle for women's suffrage. - Wikipedia

title: FPV USB OTG Video Reciever Case

description.text:
Just getting into FPV Quad flying. Fat sharks are great but the price can be a little high. Many other options exist but rarely do you see anything based on whats you carry around daily.

Purchased an OTG (Usb plug in for cell phones) adapter online for 15 bucks. (Prices are all over the place for the same thing) after finding the following
https://www.helicomicro.com/2016/12/19/5-8g-mini-fpv-otg-receiver-le-test/
everything looked pretty good and it worked well.

I removed it from the heat shrink to conformal coat it (waterproof) and decided to try making an enclosure to house it while securing it to some cheap VR goggles.

Not really much else to say, I'm sure someone else can make it look better, or have some other fun with it.

Flsun Kossel Delta

Okay, my first attempt at making an Overwatch Spinner. I was asked to come up with one for a co-worker and this is what I came up with. I concealed all of the bearings from the front and made it a pin style so that it will spin easier. This uses standard 608 skate board bearings. You might have to use a press/hammer to get the pin to go in, it's pretty snug.

Tool to cut the tops off K-Cups for recycling.
There is still a small plastic ring on the aluminum top but far better than tossing the whole K-Cup.
Uses a standard razor, an M3 nut and screw.
3/9/2017 - Added new version which places the Blade 1mm higher. Fixes an issue where some k-cups were glued to the sides and tore when being opened.

Step 1: Print

I printed with supports enabled in Cura. I'm not sure if printable without I didn't chance it.

Step 2: Remove all support material

I scraped out the support material with a small screwdriver.

Step3: Insert nut

I press fit the M3 nut into the bottom with a pair of pliers. Fits snug.

step 4: assemble

Assemble the whole thing and tie it together with an M3 screw. (I only had 10mm screws. You could likely get away with 5mm or smaller."

step 5: Adjust blade and tighten

Adjust the blade till the required about of blade is sticking out. I used the full available length, but my razor blade was very used and very dull.

title: Flsun i3 x/z axis 70 mm redesign
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - Share Alike

description.text:
These are replacement z-axis brackets for the flsun i3 printer, they are modified from the stock version and have not yet been tested. Here are a list of improvements:

  • x-axis rods are vertically in line with the belt, which means, no more z-axis bracket twist when applying tension to the x-axis belt
  • x-axis rod holes include end stops ensuring that the brackets don't twist when applying tension to the x-axis belt
  • integrated x-axis belt tensioner utilizing the same tensioner from the y-axis bed belt

Updated Feb 20 2017:

  • x-axis rods are vertically in line with the belt, which means, no more z-axis bracket twist when applying tension to the x-axis belt
  • x-axis rod holes include end stops ensuring that the brackets don't twist when applying tension to the x-axis belt
  • x-axis rod holes are now spaced by 70mm to match the prusa standard, http://reprap.org/wiki/Vertical_X_Axis_Standard, this will allow any standard prusa gantry found online to be installed on these rails

Updated Feb 23 2017:

  • extruder gantry bracket with integrated belt tensioner uploaded
  • x-axis belt tensioner uploaded
  • extruder gantry bracket includes adjustability in z-axis in three positions for alternate extruders should you choose to install an alternate extruder with a shorter height
  • extruder bracket includes reinforcement to stay rigid after installation with a ridge for the bracket to rest on

Updated Feb 25 2017:

  • x axis carriage updated to include four increments to adjust the height of the extruder bracket for those that have upgraded their extruders. the increments are sized at 5 mm
  • the x axis carriage now has a location to add the limit switch which is also used

I have to print the parts to test fit everything, so note that I have not printed these yet.

I'd like to thank Mak-a-face for the belt tensioner idea, it was the best pre-designed option I found: http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:745934/#files
I'd also like to suggest that the z axis motors be upgraded while you perform this upgrade: http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:2090980

Updated Mar 4 2017:

  • z axis left and right and extruder carriage bracket holes for bearings now corrected to 14.9mm for 15mm bearings
  • files labeled v1.2 have been updated

Updated Mar 24 2017:

  • minor alignment changes on all parts
  • added a temporary mounting hole for a blower fan
  • files labeled v1.3 have been updated

Updated Mar 26-31 2017:

  • extruder carriage bracket stl alignment issues, orientation also corrected
  • extruder v1.6 added to kit, this is an optional component if bearing fitment is an issue, the v1.6 version allows for more compliance in the design similar to that of the z axis left and right brackets. once I validate the print, I will remove the v1.3 version
  • minor adjustment on extruder bracket for better fit, file updated to v1.4
  • holes added to visually see if the x axis rods are inserted into the left and right brackets all the way in
  • lead screw nuts mounting holes on left and right brackets reduced in size to accept an M3 hole without the use of a nut
  • Gantry bracket holes for extruder bracket reduced in size for tight fit for m3 screws

Note update Apr 21 2017:
I've modeled a version of the z axis brackets with 45 mm spacing for those that would like to print the original prusa carriage models found online. The files can be found here: http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:2265383

comments.author: pasquale8120

comments.text:
the way i see it, the flsun has a design flaw in that the x axis belt is not in the same plane as the z axis bearing rods. This causes the whole x axis assembly to twist on acceleration since there is no lateral support. Your fix goes a long way to solving this.
Of course the other problem is the Z lead screws. They need to be either free floating (ie not hard coupled to the x carriage ends) or they need to be soft coupled to the z motors AND supported by bearings top and bottom. If neither of these two are done then the sloppy hard coupling between the z motor and z lead screw will create z wobble.
Currently I am using the original flsun x carriage but..... I am using the provided soft coupling for the z motor and putting in bearings top and bottom of the z lead screws. This will turn the z lead screws into real lateral supports just like the z rods and will properly support the x carriage during accelerations. (note that my kit came with lead screws and not cheap threaded rods and so they are as straight as the z rods). If this does not have the desired results I will try your thing (more work and time to implement). Of course simply turning down the X acceleration makes a large improvement to the artifacts created by the flsun x carriage design. thanks for your work. If and when i try it i will post before and after test prints.

comments.text: Have you considered making the x axis decoupled from the leadscrew? This  would allow any lead screw imperfections to not be directly transfered into the x axis as well.
comments.author: jondevos

comments.text: I was considering it, but I decided not to consider that the X/Z axis left/right brackets have end stops built in, these shouldn't be necessary. That was the primary drive of the redesign. I'm currently using decouplers and the gantry assembly tends to get snagged on the way down.
comments.author: jondevos

comments.text: fyi, antibacklash nuts wouldn't make sense in this situation. The Z axis only moves in one direction, up from its endstop.  Backlash only occurs when you change directions.
comments.author: jmzjamz

comments.text: You're right, but backlash also occurs if the acceleration of z-axis is set too high. So the nuts should resolve this issue. Although I don't think the anti-backlash nuts would do a lot since the backlash only occurs on initiation of z-axis movement from 0,0,0. During normal operation, I don't notice any backlash.
comments.author: jmzjamz

comments.text: Sorry if I seemed negative. An overhaul of the z/x axis of this printer is long overdue, glad you are taking it on.

comments.text:
Oh not at all! I didn't read it that way at least ;)
I've been skeptical about the backlash myself. I ordered the special nuts I found on banggood for a couple bucks more so as an experiment to see if it would change anything on the printing side of things. As I mentioned, I really don't see an issue with my prints that I can attribute directly to backlash, but being that the stepper motor screws are ACME threaded screws and not proper lead screws, it would inherently have some slop.

author: BoyDrone

title: Orbus
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - Share Alike

description.text: These two "orb" sculptures were the result of teaching myself the latest version (2.0) of MeshMixer: I wanted to see how easy it would be to draw a symmetrical stencil on a sphere and extrude it, turning it into it's own volume. Turns out to be pretty easy. I made orb01 first, and refined the process with orb02 that has a bit more detail.

MeshMixer will auto-generate it's own support structure, so there is a version of each orb uploaded with the provided support (see attached pic): You shouldn't need to generate any of your own. That being said, I couldn't get orb02 to print successfully with the provided support: At a certain point some of the supports would snap off, causing overhang print failures. Because of that, I provided a non-support version of orb02: Makerware did a fine job of auto-creating supports for it.
Both orbs were printed with these settings on my Replicator 1:
  • Orange PLA, later spray painted metallic silver and gold.
  • No raft: orb01 used the built-in support. orb02 used Makerware support.
  • Extruded @ 220 deg, HBP off. Removable glass bed with blue painters tape.
  • 2 shells, 10% infill. 270 micron layer height (lo res).

comments.text:
So hier mal das nächste Update:
Habe nochmal den linken Arm sowie das linke Bein mit PETG und mehr Wandstärke gedruckt. Jetzt brechen die Kugelgelenkhalter nicht mehr aus. Jedoch ist recht viel Spiel in den Gelenken, speziel die Knie. So wie sie bei mir aktuell sind, wird der Roboter nicht ohne Hilfe stehen können. Wenn ich aber alles geschliffen habe und 1-2 Ladungen Spritzspachtel über Gelenk und Halter hab sollte es passen. Das Gelenk im Arm ist mit etwas nachbearbeitung kein Problem. Mein größtes Problem sind die Bolzen. Diese habe ich trotz Vollmaterialdruck und mehreren versuchen nicht Stabil hinbekommen. Es brechen immer die enden ab.Ich bin am überlegen auf Gewindeschrauben umzubauen. Solltest du in der nächsten Zeit dein Imbusschraubenupdate Online stellen, warte ich noch mit der anderen Seite. Hierbei sind meiner Meinung nach Die Gelenke in den Knien und Schultergelenke am nötigsten, zu Überarbeiten.

comments.text:
So hier mal meine ersten Testberichte. Fuß Rechts scheint eine falsche Datei zu sein. Die Lower Leg sowie der Link passen nicht in die H
alterung. Habe jetzt Fuß Links einfach gespiegelt. Die Kugelgelenke lassen sich einwandfrei drucken, jedoch sind die Gelenk halter in den Teilen mit 3er Wanddicke bei PLA zu brüchig. Beim eindrücken des Kugelgelenks brechen diese einfach aus. Sonst sind alle Teile vom Bein mit Support und 30% infill mit 0,2mm Layerhöhe problemlos zu drucken. Aktuell versuche ich die abgebrochenen Halter rauszufräsen und nochmal als Vollmaterial zu drucken um diese dann da einzusetzen.

author: RoBotniK

description.text:
Made this design for free movement of bearing, also holding the filament spool on the bearing surface. There are guides so the filament spool won't fall between the gap of the spool holder and bearing, caused by the spacers used to hold the bearing firmly.

Print 2 of this and use the following materials:

4 x 608 ZZ or 608 2RS bearings
8 x M8 spacers
4 x M8 nuts

4 x M8 20mm screws ( anything above 16.2mm should work )
or
2 x M8 treaded bars ( in case of making a width variable spool holder for realiable filament spool holding )

Enjoy.

description.text:
I used the original holder made by Kpafuca for some time, but have since moved my printer into an enclosure.

I needed the holder to not lean back so far so Remixed it in Meshmaker to be much more upright....

this created a problem with it wanting to fall forward when filament was being pulled off so i created the support to screw it to the printer and hold it down.

I decided that it would also be a good idea to also build the top Z axis guide rail supports into the model...

All in all i love the way it looks now and its much more sturdy then the original..

This is a set of stencils for making an SPQR banner by painting with gold paint on cloth.

We used the stencils by putting some gluestick on the underside of the stencils, placing them on cloth, and then painting with Liquitex Basics Gold. Be careful that each painted part dries before you use the next stencil to avoid smudges.

No supports needed for printing. The central SPQR stencil has some bridges to hold in the disconnected parts of the Q and R.

The eagle (not included) is based on this.

The stencils are based on the vexilloid by Ssolbergj, licensed under the Creative Commons Attribution 3.0 Unported. They are designed for a 200x200 mm print bed. If you need smaller ones, you'll need to break things up into smaller pieces.

print_settings.Notes:: I was messing with new PLA's and various settings, so my prints didn't come out the best, and some parts are better than others... still usable, if not the prettiest!

description.text:
I modified the awesome Pix-E camera by altering the body to accept a "flash" housing. I modeled the housing in 123D Design to accept a 20mm Transparent LED Lens Reflector Collimator (8 Degree). I glued an IR LED into the back of the reflector using E6000, and used a PI NoIR camera module instead of the regular PI Camera module.

There wasn't a lot of space in the flash corner for screws, so the flash housing snaps into holes I made in my remixed body, and the LED goes through a central hole between the clip holes.

I'm infatuated with all things spooky, so I made this with an IR camera, but you could easily use the regular PI Camera and a bright (or colored!) LED and use it as an actual light for regular photos. Just make sure whatever LED you use, you put the proper resistor inline!

I also had to use an N-Channel Power MOSFET to power the LED while controlling the gate with a pin on the RPi. (Unfortunately, I found that the software PWM wasn't stable enough to use as control for variable brightness on the LED, so I just used more resistors!)

I only altered the code to initialize the new LED pin, and turn it on before the pictures begin, and turn it off after they're done.

I also modified the back to more tightly fit a Breadboard-friendly SPDT Slide Switch (I bought mine on Adafruit).
